node.title: Children, Coping With Loss, Are Pandemic’s ‘Forgotten Grievers’
node.alt: Courtney Grund’s 16-year-old son said he was having mood swings and suicidal thoughts since his father’s death. Teachers and friends don’t understand his situation, he said. Ms. Grund signed him up for grief counseling after one friend expressed concern.
node.description: A bipartisan group led by two former governors is urging President Biden to help an estimated 167,000 children who have lost parents or caregivers.
node.content: ["WASHINGTON \u2014 Courtney Grund, whose husband died of Covid-19 in August, got an alarming text message last week: Her 16-year-old son was \u201ctalking about self-harm,\u201d according to the message, sent by his friend. She quickly signed him up for grief counseling, she said in a tearful interview, using her maiden name to protect his privacy.", "John Jackson, a disabled veteran on a fixed income, said he had struggled to find help for his 14-year-old daughter, whose mother died in the pandemic. \u201cI can see it in her, where she\u2019s suffering,\u201d he said.", "Pamela Addison, a reading teacher whose husband died, said she felt fortunate that she could afford therapy \u2014 $200 a session out of pocket \u2014 for her grieving 3-year-old.", "Although Congress has allocated trillions of dollars to combat the pandemic, including more than $100 million for existing children\u2019s mental health programs and $122 billion for schools, the Biden administration and lawmakers have not yet created initiatives specifically for the tens of thousands of children who have lost parents and primary caregivers to Covid-19.", "Behind the scenes, leaders of a bipartisan coalition of experts in education, the economy and health \u2014 backed by wealthy philanthropies and headed by two former governors, Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho, a Republican, and Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, a Democrat \u2014 have been meeting with White House officials, urging them to do more.", "On Thursday \u2014 just two days after the surgeon general warned that young people were facing \u201cdevastating\u201d mental health issues related to the pandemic \u2014 that group, the Covid Collaborative, will release a report estimating that more than 167,000 children in the United States have lost parents or in-home caregivers to the disease.", "The collaborative is asking President Biden to initiate a national campaign to identify these children and, with help from the private sector, take steps to improve their emotional and economic well-being. Its recommendations include offering them mental health care and creating a \u201cCovid Bereaved Children\u2019s Fund,\u201d similar to a fund established after the Sept. 11 attacks, to provide up to $10,000 to families in need.", "\u201cThe president is uniquely positioned to put an official imprimatur on the call in this report to coordinate all resources, public and private, at every level of government and every level of the private sector and philanthropy to help these children,\u201d Mr. Patrick said in an interview.", "\u201cIt\u2019s a tragedy not of their making,\u201d he added, \u201cbut they\u2019re our kids. They belong to us, and all we are saying is, \u2018Let\u2019s act like it.\u2019\u201d", "The report, titled \u201cHidden Pain,\u201d estimates that more than 70 percent of the bereaved children are 13 or younger. It is based on federal data and a modeling study led by Dan Treglia, a social policy researcher at the University of Pennsylvania.", "Communities of color are disproportionately affected. Dr. Treglia, who is also part of the collaborative, said racial and ethnic disparities in caregiver loss from Covid-19 exceeded the already stark disparities in coronavirus deaths.", "Parents and young people left behind said the push by the Covid Collaborative was welcome news, if only to force officials in Washington to recognize this new cohort of bereaved children.", "Ms. Grund picked up her son from school last week after she got the text from his friend; he has not yet returned.", "He went to his first group therapy session Tuesday evening. In an interview, he said he was having mood swings and suicidal thoughts, and had not wanted to leave his room. He would like to see initiatives that better equip teachers and school officials to help grieving students.", "\u201cNo one knew how to deal with what I was going through, so it was hard for the teachers to communicate to me,\u201d he said, adding that while he could talk to his friends, it had not helped much. \u201cI can share with them, but it\u2019s in one ear and out the other,\u201d he said. \u201cThey don\u2019t completely understand and, like, process the whole situation.\u201d", "A spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services, Kirsten Allen, said the administration \u201chas made a number of investments and launched several initiatives covering a wide range of mental health priorities \u2014 including support for children who have lost parents.\u201d", "She cited the surgeon general\u2019s advisory and the expansion of several existing programs. In May, for example, the department announced it was releasing $14.2 million, allocated by Congress through the American Rescue Plan, to expand access to pediatric mental health care. The rescue plan also provided money for suicide prevention programs and a program to improve care and access to services for \u201ctraumatized children.\u201d", "John Bridgeland, the collaborative\u2019s founder and chief executive officer, said expanding existing programs was not enough. \u201cWe need a focused effort to help the unbearable loss of these 167,000 children,\u201d he said.", "Losing a parent or a caregiver is hard for a child in ordinary times. But experts in grief counseling and school officials say the pandemic has exacted a particular toll.", "\u201cThe death of a parent is something that we deal with all the time \u2014 not just with Covid,\u201d said Susan Gezon Morgan, a school nurse in Emmett, Idaho, a small city outside Boise. \u201cBut I think the fact that Covid is in the news and so sudden, and oftentimes it\u2019s a young parent, that it seems so much more traumatizing.\u201d", "In a small community like Emmett, where everyone knows everyone else, Ms. Morgan said, the grief cuts both ways. Grieving children lose their privacy, but they also have a tight-knit community to provide support. In big cities, it is another story.", "Mr. Jackson, of Reisterstown, Md., just outside Baltimore, is home-schooling his daughter, Akeerah, in part because he fears her peers will be insensitive, encouraging her to \u201cjust get over\u201d her loss.", "When Akeerah\u2019s mother, Cathy Fulcher, died, Mr. Jackson got a note from the Baltimore County school system saying she could delay turning in her grades, but little in the way of guidance. Soon afterward, he said, he started looking for a place for his daughter to get therapy.", "\u201cOne was $250; they didn\u2019t take any type of insurance,\u201d he said. \u201cThat was just for us to come in for an evaluation. That\u2019s just not in the budget.\u201d", "Eventually he found Roberta\u2019s House, a grief support center for Baltimore families. There, Akeerah said, she has learned how to cope with her grief by drawing and writing in a journal, and she is now a \u201cpeer ambassador,\u201d leading sessions for other teens. She has also attended Camp Erin, a free camp for grieving children offered in cities across the country.", "Both are funded by the New York Life Foundation, which also backs the Covid Collaborative and has created a website, grievingstudents.org, to provide information for educators as part of its \u201cgrief-sensitive schools\u201d initiative, which predates the pandemic. The vice president of the foundation, Maria Collins, says many of its programs have waiting lists.", "\u201cIt\u2019s known in this field that the young person is the forgotten griever,\u201d she said, adding that the foundation was open to working with the federal government and would be \u201ceager to provide tangible support, financial and otherwise, for Covid-bereaved children.\u201d", "The collaborative envisions $2 billion to $3 billion for the bereavement fund, possibly supplemented by money from private foundations. It would help parents struggling with everything from rent payments to their children\u2019s academic performance to finding the right therapy at a reasonable cost.", "The report builds on similar research: The journal Pediatrics, relying on data through June 30, before the wave of infections caused by the Delta variant, reported in October that more than 120,000 American children had lost parents or caregivers from Covid-19.", "The researchers who conducted the collaborative\u2019s study found that Black and Hispanic children were roughly two and a half times as likely as whites to be bereaved as a result of the pandemic, while Native American children were nearly four times as likely. Dr. Treglia, whose research focuses on vulnerable populations, said the number of bereaved children grew quickly during the Delta surge in part because it hit so many adults of childbearing age.", "\u201cThere is an extraordinary responsibility to care for those children,\u201d he said. \u201cSo many of them were facing economic and other hardships even before the pandemic began, and certainly before they lost a caregiver. Now they are facing their darkest days.\u201d", "Some parents whose spouses were frontline workers say they would like at least some recognition from Washington that their loved ones died while trying to protect others.", "Ms. Addison, whose husband was a hospital speech pathologist in Paterson, N.J., runs a support group called Young Widows and Widowers of Covid-19. She estimates that 95 percent of her 900 members have children.", "\u201cYou invite athletes to the White House because they\u2019ve won a championship; why not invite families who lost their loved one because they went into a hospital, they went into a school that wasn\u2019t really safe?\u201d she said. \u201cYou see when a military person dies there is this big celebration of their life and the kids know their parent is a hero. Our kids need that.\u201d"]
